message_1:
What is the enthalpy change for the reduction of 1 mole of Fe2O3(s) to Fe(s) at standard conditions, given the following thermochemical equation:

Fe2O3(s) + 3 CO(g) → 2 Fe(s) + 3 CO2(g)

and the standard enthalpies of formation:

ΔHf°[Fe2O3(s)] = -824.2 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[Fe(s)] = 0 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[CO(g)] = -110.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change for the reduction of 1 mole of Fe2O3(s) to Fe(s) at standard conditions, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the given thermochemical equation:

Fe2O3(s) + 3 CO(g) → 2 Fe(s) + 3 CO2(g)

The enthalpy change (ΔH°) can be calculated as follows:

ΔH° = [2 × ΔHf°(Fe) + 3 × ΔHf°(CO2)] - [ΔHf°(Fe2O3) + 3 × ΔHf°(CO)]

Using the given standard enthalpies of formation:

ΔH° = [2 × 0 kJ/mol + 3 × (-393.5 kJ/mol)] - [(-824.2 kJ/mol) + 3 × (-110.5 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = [0 + (-1180.5 kJ)] - [(-824.2 kJ) + (-331.5 kJ)]

ΔH° = (-1180.5 kJ) - (-1155.7 kJ)

ΔH° = -24.8 kJ/mol

So, the enthalpy change for the reduction of 1 mole of Fe2O3(s) to Fe(s) at standard conditions is -24.8 kJ/mol.
